titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Farafra Arabic
titleStmt.author: Gunda Kinzl

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Farāfra is an oasis in the Egyptian Western desert and lies between the Baḥariyya and Dākhla oases in the Wādi al-Gadīd governorate. It is the smallest one in a chain of oases located in a depression of the Sahara desert. In recent times, tourism and agriculture are changing the face of the region. Many of the about 20,000 people who inhabit the oasis today are from the Nile valley.

Although there is no isogloss that separates the oases dialects from the Nile valley dialects, they show a distinct development that makes them a dialect group of its own. Farāfra and Dākhla are connected more closely to each other than to other oases or the Nile valley. In morphology, there is a connection between Farāfra and Baḥariyya, which is probably due to marriage and trade relations. Behnstedt and Woidich 1982 discuss the oases dialects, including a short text example from Farāfra. Behnstedt and Woidich’s Die ägyptisch-arabischen Dialekte also contain data on Farāfra, volume III part 2 contains texts.
